conclusion: To find the acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds, the velocity-time graph will be analyzed.
The graph shows velocity (v) in m·s⁻¹ on the y-axis and time (t) in seconds on the x-axis.
From 0 to 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m·s⁻¹.
From 1 to 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m·s⁻¹ to 0 m·s⁻¹.
From 2 to 3 seconds, the velocity continues decreasing linearly from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, represented by the slope of the velocity-time graph.
During the interval from 1 to 3 seconds, the velocity changes at a constant rate (linear decrease).
Initial velocity at t = 1s is v₁ = 2 m·s⁻¹, and final velocity at t = 3s is v₂ = -2 m·s⁻¹.
From 1s to 2s, velocity changes from 2 m·s⁻¹ to 0 m·s⁻¹, so a₁ = (0 - 2)/1 = -2 m·s⁻².
From 2s to 3s, velocity changes from 0 m·s⁻¹ to -2 m·s⁻¹, so a₂ = (-2 - 0)/1 = -2 m·s⁻².
Both segments have the same acceleration of -2 m·s⁻², confirming the calculation.
The acceleration of the particle during the time interval from 1 to 3 seconds is -2 m·s⁻².
